Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: The role of oxygen fugacity in calc-alkaline differentiation and the creation of continental crust at the Aleutian arc
Award.AbstractNarration: This proposal seeks to examine the role of oxygen variations in the origin of the calc-alkaline magmas that erupt at subduction-related volcanoes (arc volcanoes). In particular, the PIs seek to determine how oxygen varies during differentiation and degassing, and see how it varies along strike of the Aleutian arc as a function of material derived from the subducted slab. The work will also include an experimental study of the relationship and interplay between H2O and fO2 during magma formation, a critical question with implications for the formation of continental crust. The PIs note that the Aleutian arc features local and regional variations in numerous geochemical features, but lacks the complexities introduced when magmas move through continental crust. The proposed work includes novel (micro XANES analysis of the ferrous/ferric ratio in glasses (a proxy for oxygen content), especially glass inclusions in mineral. Water, CO2 and major and trace elements (including Cl and S) will also be analyzed. The PIs also propose an experimental program in which fO2 is varied at constant water content. The experimental glasses will be analyzed using the same techniques as described for the natural glasses. Broader impacts include a new interactive exhibit at the Smithsonian that will include an on-line component. Material from the exhibits will be incorporated into undergraduate curricula. There will be undergraduate mentoring through REU and/or senior thesis, as well as mentoring of grad students and a post-doc.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Subduction is a process driven by plate tectonics, whereby two tectonic plates converge and one plate hosting oceanic lithosphere descends into the mantle. Dehydration reactions driven by increased pressure and temperature in the descending plate aid in melt generation, and the resultant melt ultimately feeds volcanic systems that overlie subduction zones. The explosivity of these subduction-zone volcanic systems, which is modified by magma chemistry and the dissolved volatile content of the magmas, impacts human populations located near volcanoes. Magma composition and species of gases (e.g., H2O or SO2) released by subduction zone magmas are strongly impacted by oxygen fugacity (fO2), making fO2 a fundamentally important parameter to explore in subduction zone magmagenesis. Therefore, the primary objective of this proposal is to evaluate the relative importance of fO (together with H2O and magmatic bulk composition) in generating calc-alkaline magmas erupted at arc volcanoes in the Aleutians.

The Aleutian arc is an ideal natural laboratory for studying the production of subduction-zone melts, including the mechanisms responsible for the petrogenesis of variable magma chemistries found in individual subduction zones; the study benefits from the observation that the Aleutians arc has erupted lavas that range from strongly calc-alkaline to mildly tholeiitic. The PIs involved in the study relate dissolved volatiles budgets, redox state (i.e., Fe3+ /Total Fe), major- and trace-element concentrations, and isotopic signatures of melt inclusions isolated from a suite Aleutian lavas. In order to place constraints on the evolution of calc-alkaline melts, these data, measured in natural samples, are paired with experimental constraints that parameterize the influence of H2O, fO2, and bulk composition on the phase equilibria of Aleutian parental magmas. Additionally, owing to the roles that H2O, fO2, and magmatic bulk composition play in models of how Earth’s continents initially formed, this study has implications for the origin of continental crust. Finally, crustal assimilation and magma mixing can play important roles in the evolution of magmas. Lead isotopes are sensitive to these processes; therefore this study also targets melt inclusions for Pb-isotopic analyses to identify these magmatic processes, and to integrate these observations with redox-state constraints and major-, trace- and volatile-element concentration datasets obtained on the inclusions.

The samples for the study were collected in the Aleutians in September 2015. At this time, the PI developed and published a technique for in situ measurement of Pb isotopes in melt inclusions by Laser-Ablation Multi-Collector Inductively-Coupled Plasma Mass Spectrometry (LA-MCICP-MS). This represents an important new analytical tool for the PIs and graduate students involved with this study, and permits analysis of small samples: the technique is optimized for samples 110 µm in diameter, but smaller samples can be targeted (with a reduction in measurement precision).

The UCSB LA-MCICP-MS facility is actively growing, and it continues to reach an increasingly larger geochemical community. Thus, this new analytical tool will allow the UCSB community, collaborators, and guest scientists to employ in situ Pb-isotope analyses on small samples (<110 µm diameter) in geochemical tracer studies. This project also provided important monetary resources for an early-career PI (Jackson did not yet have tenure when this award was submitted for review), and it provided resources for two female PIs (Kelley and Cottrell). Additionally, this project provided invaluable field experience in the Aleutians for a UCSB graduate student, Katherine Sheppard. This award also funded the production of a documentary video about field work made available to the public on Youtube ("Expedition to Arctic Volcanoes"; https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Q9ebwokEUJk). This outreach product inspires the public to explore STEM opportunities. The Kid’s Post column of the Washington Post covered the educational video (http://wapo.st/2mkOtLI?tid=ss_mail), and it received an award (Telly Award, Bronze, in the category of "Video/Shows/Segments, General Science & Technology”). The documentary was selected for presentation at a French film festival about scientific expeditions (Les Rencontres Montagnes et Sciences); the documentary will be subtitled in French and will be shown in Clarmont Ferrand and Grenoble in the fall and winter of 2017/2018. Finally, with support from this proposal, PI Jackson published 10 articles (all of which specifically acknowledge this grant) in international, peer-reviewed journals.
